0.text: Good afternoon and welcome to the first of the webinar series on browsing genes and genomes with Ensembl.

7.text: My name's Emily Perry and I'm the Ensembl Outreach Project Leader

11.text: and I'll be presenting first of the webinars that you'll see as part of this series.

16.text: Those of you who were actually at the webinar might be a bit confused

20.text: because this is not exactly the same webinar as you were present at.

24.text: Unfortunately the recording of that failed so I had to to re-record this.

29.text: So what we're going to come over the next seven weeks is what Ensembl is,

34.text: what kind of data you can get from Ensembl,

37.text: how to browse and navigate the Ensembl website,

40.text: and finally, and I often think this is the most important one, where to go for help and documentation.

46.text: So today's webinar will be an introduction to Ensembl with me.

51.text: Next week you will have Denise who will talk to you about Ensembl genes.

54.text: That will be followed by Helen who will take you through BioMart, a data export tool.

59.text: And then Denise will be back to talk about variation data.

62.text: Helen will tell you about comparing genes and genomes with Ensembl compara.

67.text: And then I'll talk about the Ensembl regulatory build, finding features that regulate genes.

72.text: And then we'll finish on the 5th of May with Ben Moore, talking about uploading your data to Ensembl

78.text: and advanced ways to access Ensembl data.

81.text: So the way each of these sessions is going to work is I will

86.text: start by giving a presentation about what the data or the tool is and how we

90.text: produce or process the data that goes into it.

93.text: That will be followed by a demonstration when we show how to get the data or use the tool.

100.text: And then there'll be exercises which are available on the Train Online which hopefully all of you have already found.

107.text: For those of you in the webinars, since this is not live, unfortunately,

114.text: this is possibly not so relevant, but if you're in the the next webinars that come along

118.text: there'll be a chat box so you can ask questions during the webinar

123.text: and my colleagues will respond as the talk is going on

128.text: So this is the way it will work in the next one as well as what we did yesterday which didn't, unfortunately, record.

136.text: There are also course exercises so after each webinar there's be exercises put up in the Train Online course

145.text: This video will take the place of the text that you see in each section,

151.text: and the links to the next pages will become exercises which will also appear in the page hierarchy on the left.

159.text: And if you haven't done so already, you welcome to join our Facebook group.

164.text: There you can discuss the exercises with each other and also you can ask our help as well.

171.text: There's a link in the online course if you want to join the Facebook group.

175.text: If you prefer not to work with Facebook then you can email us on helpdesk@ensembl.org

180.text: to  ask for help with anything to do with the exercises. There are solutions available for them as well.

188.text: So without further ado, I'll get on to talking about the basics and the introduction to Ensembl

194.text: So normally in a live workshop I would

198.text: get other people to answer this question; today I'll have to answer it myself:

203.text: Why do we need genome browsers?

205.text: Well genomes are big. They contain lots and lots of data and we're producing them at a fairly massive rate.

211.text: And if you look at the kind of data we're producing, it basically looks like this. it's completely meaningless.

218.text: The only way this data means something is if we work with it, and process it and do something with it.

225.text: which is what we're trying to do in genome browsers.

228.text: So these are three major genome browsers that are out there

232.text: There's ourselves, Ensembl, that I'm tlaking to you about today,

236.text: but the other major ones are UCSC and and NCBI Map Viewer, which are both very good browsers from the United States

244.text: and it really seems to be personal preference as to which one people seem to prefer.

249.text: We have lots and lots of data in Ensembl: we have what we call Gene-builds for about 70 species;

256.text: we take all of our genes and we compare them pairwise to each other and we produce gene trees;

261.text: we do what we call a regulatory build, which pulls in data from ENCODE, Roadmap Epigenomics, Blueprint

268.text: and predict the locations of features such as enhancers and promoters;

274.text: we have a variation display which allows you to look at known variation

280.text: and you can also use our VEP tool to analyse your own;

283.text: we have various ways to display on your own data;

286.text: and we have various methods to export our data; we have BioMart which is a point and click tool;

293.text:
and we also have APIs for programmatic access: we have a Perl API and a REST
API.

299.text: And one of the really cool things is that all of our code and all of our software is

303.text: completely open source and free to use.

307.text: Everything that I've just highlighted in red things that are special and unique to us,

312.text: So we make all of our own genes, we produce all the gene trees, we make the regulary build,

318.text: we made the VEP, we're the only browser which has got BioMart,

323.text: we're the only browser with programmatic access, and the only browser which is completely open source.

330.text: And you can access Ensembl data at various different scales.

333.text: You can access things like genes on a one-by-one basis

337.text: you can access groups of genes or you can access all the genes in an entire genome.

343.text: And so for one-by-one access you're largely looking at the main browser or the mobile site.

349.text: You can also look at groups or one-by-one with BioMart, the REST API and the VEP.

355.text: The Perl API and MySQL database are suitable for looking at every possible scale.

361.text: And the FTP site is really for downloading whole genome data,

366.text: so maybe, every FASTA sequence in the database, something like that.

371.text: We are used all over the world, so these are just our top 10 countries

375.text: but I only need to look at the list of registrations for this course to see that we span far beyond the top 10

384.text: that you can see here, and this is just based on our website statistics.

391.text: And Ensembl covers vertebrates, so we try and cover a wide range of taxonomic space,

396.text: we try and cover biologically important species, such as model organisms, agricultural species

401.text: and conservationally important species as well.

406.text: And if you're eagle-eyed, you might have spotted that there are some non-vertebrates shown on this tree:

412.text: we also have C. elegans, Drosophila melanogaster and Saccharomyces cerevisiae in the database.

418.text:
These are in for a couple of reasons: one of
them is historical,

421.text: and the other reason is that they're actually really useful to have around when you're making gene trees.

426.text: If you have a very unrelated species you can use it to anchor the tree more effectively.

432.text: If you work with non-vertebrates, you'll probably be interested in our sister site which is ensemblgenomes.org

439.text: Ensembl Genomes has five mini sites which cover

442.text: bacteria, protists, fungi, metazoa and plants and they all work in pretty much the same way as Ensembl.

449.text: Throughout this course you will find that there are a few exercises where we send you

454.text: the way of one of these mini sites. We will also point out any special features

460.text: of the mini sites and that are important when you're looking at particular kinds of data.

466.text: So the differences between Ensembl and Ensembl Genomes: Ensembl's been around since 2000

473.text: it was conceived as part of the human genome project, whereas Ensembl Genomes is a bit newer.

479.text: We have the different species specialisation.

482.text: But the major difference is the annotation. Ensembl is all done in-house

487.text: so we annotate all our own genes, whereas Ensembl Genomes works with the scientific communities.

493.text: And you access them via two different URLs, but I'll point out where you can jump from one to the other and once you're in there.

503.text: We also have a release cycle. The main benefit of the release cycle is it means that everything is traceable

508.text: So just earlier this month we had Ensembl 84 coming out

512.text: and over the next few months what we'll find is

515.text: various kinds of new data comes in, such as new assemblies

519.text: software updates, gene sets, then, for anything new, we'll need to re-run our comparative genomics

526.text: We'll add in variation data, regulation data, as well as updates to any interfaces.

532.text: And that will bring out the next release which will be Ensembl 85.

535.text: We're having a bit of a longer release than normal this time and so that will be out in July.

541.text: And the main benefit is that everything becomes traceable,

545.text: so when you find data in Ensembl and you note down in your lab book which release you got it from

550.text: then if you go back to that data in six months time,

555.text:
you can check and not just the current
version of the data which may have changed

559.text: but also the older version of the data and you'll know which version to look at.

565.text: I just, briefly, before I start showing you what's in Ensembl,

570.text: want to go over genome assemblies, because this seems to be something that a lot of people aren't totally familiar with.

576.text: So there's currently no technology available where you can start at one end of a chromosome

583.text: and sequence all the way along to the other end.

586.text: That would be wonderful and I'm sure somebody's working on inventing it but it's not out yet.

592.text: Which means that when we sequence genomes we have to use other methods,

597.text: so we have to cut the genomes up into small chunks, sequence the chunks,

602.text: and put them back together. This inevitably leads to mistakes

606.text: There will be regions of the genome where we just haven't got sequence,

610.text: there will be regions where we could put it back together but we put it back together in order.

616.text: So this creates a genome assembly which again, we stamp number or a name,

621.text: and we can use this whenever working with genomes and it's important to note down

626.text: which genome assembly we're working on because if then somebody comes along

630.text: repairs a bunch of the mistakes produces a new version of the genome assembly,

635.text: you can know whether you're looking at the same one or a different one

638.text: and, of course, go back and try to find the one you were looking at previously.

642.text: Another thing to remember about genome assemblies is because we're cutting up

650.text: genomes from real individuals, every piece of the genome is part of a real human or

657.text: animal or plant or whatever it might be. So the human genome is made up of chunks of genome,

665.text: put together from a number of different people, and they've all got accession numbers,

671.text: whereas other genomes, for example the cat genome is all made up of one cat, which happens to be named Cinnamon.

680.text: But the point is that every piece of the genome we're looking at is one individual's sequence.

686.text: So this can mean that if that individual has got a slightly unusual sequence in that region

692.text: that still happens to be in the genome.

696.text: So, we're going to do some hands-on:

698.text: I'm now going to give you a demonstration of looking at the Ensembl homepage

702.text: and how to find out information about species and genome assemblies in Ensembl.

707.text: And then we're going to go and have a look at the human genome

710.text: and we're going to manipulate the view to see the data we're interested in.

714.text: So we're going to look at a specific region.

716.text: So I'm going to jump out of my presentation

719.text: and I've already opened up a tab with the Ensembl browser in.

724.text: And there's a few things I'd like to point out on the homepage for you.

728.text: The first thing is this big blue bar runs along the top.

731.text: Now the blue bar is visible on every page you go into in Ensembl

736.text: which means you've always got a link back to the homepage,

740.text: you've always got a search box, you've always got links to help and documentation.

746.text: We've also go a 'What's new in release 84',

750.text: so if you're not sure which release you're looking at, if you go to this box over here,

754.text: it will tell you what the current version is

757.text: and it will also tell you all the new things that came out.

759.text: so when a new release comes out you might want to go and have a look and see what's changed

764.text: If I scroll down to the page there's a little link here,

768.text: and you'll see this on nearly every page, that says 'View in archive site'.

772.text: When I click on 'View in archive site' it then gives me a list of previous versions of Ensembl

777.text: that I can jump to. So if I've noted down in by lab book that I got my data from Ensembl 80

783.text: I can then go back and have a look at Ensembl 80 and see what data is actually available there.

790.text: I'll just close that for now, I won't need to go and have a look.

794.text: I've also got some links to some common tasks that people like to do with Ensembl.

801.text: I've got another search box which has the added benefit of a species selector so you can search only a specific species.

807.text: And over here, more information about some of the genomes in Ensembl.

812.text: So I'm going to go and click on 'View full list of all Ensembl species'

817.text: and this will now show me a full list of all of the 70 vertebrate species that we have.

823.text: So we've got the images, the common names, the latin names, the taxon IDs and also the assembly.

830.text: You can obviously scroll down and search that way,

833.text: but the quick way to find your favoutire species is to type it into the find a species box

838.text: over on the right-hand side here.

841.text: I can now jump into human.

845.text: This is the species home page so I can see what's new in human in the most recent release

851.text: as well as some example regions, genes, transcripts, things like that.

856.text: But the thing I'm going to visit is 'More information and statistics',

861.text: and this gives me lots of information about the genome.

865.text: I've got a nice description here about when genome was released, who produced it,

870.text: I've got links to go and see the Genome Reference Consortium who made the genome.

876.text: I've got more information about gene annotation and also a detailed document I can read.

883.text: Over on the right hand side I have tables of data,

886.text: so I have things like the assembly version, the size of the genome,

890.text: the dates as to when things were produced and released, and then things like counts of genes.

896.text: Now you'll notice here it says GRCh38; that's the most recent version of the human genome.

903.text: But we know that many people are still working with the previous version of the human genome

910.text: So if I just hop back to the homepage you'll see there's a link here to 'Still using human GRCh37?'

918.text: and a link here as well. And these will take you to a dedicated site

922.text: which I have already opened up here, which is at grch37.ensembl.org

930.text: This a a special dedicated website where you can access data from the older version of the genome assembly.

937.text:
We keep it relatively and up-to-date as
well, not quite as at today is the main site

944.text: but there's still quite a lot there so if you're working with the older version this is where you want to go.

950.text: I'd also briefly like to show you Ensembl Genomes, so this is at ensemblgenomes.org.

957.text: It looks pretty similar. We've got links out here and over here to the different branches of Ensembl Genomes.

965.text: We've got bacteria, fungi, plants, protists and metazoa and a link back to the vertebrates

971.text: I'll just show you protists briefly and you'll see that it's basically the same as we saw with the main site

978.text: except at the top, it's purple, so we know which one we're in.

981.text: Everything else works exactly the same.

985.text: I'm just going to jump back and show you bacteria because bacteria is special.

989.text: And the reason bacteria is special that we have over 30,000 genomes in Ensembl Bacteria.

1000.text: These are all different strains, different versions of many of the same species.

1006.text: Now obviously, you can't really scroll down a list of 30,000 genomes, that would be horrendous,

1014.text: So instead we have this 'Search for a genome' option,

1017.text: so we have these two different search boxes: 'Search for a gene', put in your gene name,

1021.text: Or 'Search for a genome', which will then narrow you down to your genome of interest

1026.text: and then once you get into that, you can just search within that genome.

1030.text: So if I type in my favourite bacterial genomes, so 'Peptoclostrid...'

1036.text: so it's already starting to find it because it's an auto, except I mistyped.

1042.text: There we go, now it's working, 'Peptoclostridium difficile',

1047.text: it's already finding them because it auto-completes.

1050.text: And then I can jump to my favourite strain, 'Peptoclostridium difficile 630'

1060.text: and that takes me to a species home-page, just as I found with human.

1065.text: If I do a search now, from this search box, it will only be searching this one particular genome

1071.text: So this is a really good starting point, it really narrows you down.

1074.text: If I go into the 'Information and statistics

1079.text: you see I still have the statistics tables but I've lost that paragraph

1083.text: because we don't have anybody whose job sit and write 30,000 bits of information about the background.

1091.text: All of the genomes are imported directly

1094.text: from the European Nucleotide Archive and as shown here

1098.text: so we don't do any full annotation on the bacterial species.

1104.text: So I'm going to go back to the main browser at ensembl.org

1109.text: and now I'm going to search for a region and show you the Region in detail view.

1114.text: So I'm just going to hop back to my presentation briefly because we're going to use the search boxes now.

1122.text: Now the search boxes in Ensembl are really flexible; you can put pretty much anything into them:

1127.text: you can put gene names, GO terms, phenotypes. If you see a word or a phrase that you don't understand,

1135.text: you can put that in and it'll search our help and documentation, things like our glossary and FAQs as well

1142.text: But you can also search for coordinates. Now when you search for coordinates

1146.text: you don't actually want it to use the normal search becuase the normal search is using words;

1151.text: when you're searching for coordinates, you want it to know that they're coordinates, and bypass that.

1159.text: And the way to make sure it knows that they're coordinates is to use the correct format.

1163.text: Now the correct format for coordinates is to start with the chromosome number

1168.text: followed by a colon then the start coordinate, a dash and then the end coordinate.

1174.text: Note that there are no spaces in this.

1177.text: So what I'm going to do is I'm going to select this, and then copy it,

1182.text: and then I'm going to back into the browser.

1185.text: Now I also have to tell it what species I'm looking for,

1187.text: otherwise there are loads of species which have got that coordinate, it doesn't really know what to do with it.

1192.text: There are two ways to do this: I can choose my favourite species from the drop-down,

1197.text: so I can select human and just paste it in, or I can type human and just paste in my coordinates.

1207.text: Now when I hit 'Go' or type return, it jumps me to my region of interest

1214.text: So this is the Region in detail view and this is probably the most commonly used view in Ensembl

1221.text: and there's a few things I want to point out about it.

1225.text: The first thing is this little question mark here

1228.text: and I recommend, if you're every not sure what you're looking at in any page on Ensembl

1232.text: that you click on the question mark, because it will open up this pop-up window

1237.text: which gives you a description of the page you're looking at

1241.text: So I've got diagrams, I've got text describing what I'm looking at and in some of them, such as this one,

1248.text: I actually have a video. So if I hit play here in a moment Denise, who is doing the webinar the next week is going to appear

1256.text: "Hello, I'm Denise from the Ensembl team and I'm going to show you to explore the Region in detail view."

1262.text: I'm just going to turn her off because I'm going to tell you all the things that she's about to tell you.

1267.text: And I'll just shut this pop-up, but they are really useful if you're ever not sure what it is that you're working with.

1275.text: So the Region in detail view is made up of three images:

1281.text: the image at the top is the chromosome, the image in the middle is a kind of overview,

1286.text: and the image at the bottom is a detailed view.

1289.text: So the chromosome at the top, this is our region of interest shown in this red box here.

1294.text: You can see the centromere and you can see these white, black and grey bands going across the chromosome

1302.text: This is really old fashioned and cytogenetic banding data

1307.text: A lot of people still use it as in 'this is my favourite, this region that's been identified',

1316.text: so we do keep it in there even though the more modern way is to use genome coordinate.

1321.text: We also have these red highlighted regions at various points.

1326.text: These are haplotypes; these are highly variable regions of the genome

1331.text: that are represented as separate pieces of sequence because they are so very different between individuals.

1338.text:
individuals now one of these days I can
never get around to fly once never get

1342.text: Now one of the easy ways I can navigate around, if I want to navigate around using the chromosome

1344.text: I can do so by dragging out a box: I get given the option of marking the region of jumping to the region.

1350.text: I'll get rid of that but that's one way to navigate around.

1353.text: We start to see a bit more detail when we go into this second view, which is this overview

1360.text: So this red box, red box always means us. So this red box is us.

1365.text: And you can see a scale here shows that the whole of this region we're looking at is 1 Mb wide

1372.text: So in human, this will always be 1 Mb wide, but it will vary as to how wide we make this region

1378.text: depending on the size of the genome in that species. So in things like bacteria

1384.text: it is very small because bacteria, they have very small genomes,

1388.text: they have very small genes and they have very dense genes.

1391.text: So if you had it 1 Mb wide you could probably see the whole genome and it would be really hard and really busy.

1399.text: So we can see our chromosome bands again

1402.text: and we can also see this blue bar, which is labelled Contigs.

1405.text: Now the contigs, I mentioned earlier about how the human genome was made up

1410.text: by chunks of sequence from different individuals,

1414.text: each contig is one piece of sequence, so one single chunk,

1422.text: and the accession numbers tell us which piece it is.

1427.text: Some of them don't have an accession written on them, but they do have an accession if I click on it.

1435.text: If I click on on it I get a popup tells me what the accession of this particular contig is.

1442.text: So they do have a number.

1444.text: You can also see genes, so these big coloured blocks here, so this gold block,

1449.text: this blue block here. These are all genes.

1460.text: The labels of the genes are shown underneath them. So if I follow the left-most point of a gene straight down,

1466.text: I'll hit the left-most point of a label.

1469.text: So this big gold gene here is the SPATA5 gene. This gold gene here, if I follow it down is the FGF2 gene

1479.text: If I follow down the left-hand side and go straight down, I'll meet the matching label.

1485.text:
I can navigate around this view as well,
using this drag or select option,

1493.text: So I'm currently in this double-headed arrow which is the scroll option,

1497.text: if I click and drag anywhere in this view it moves me around, like using Google Maps.

1502.text: I've got quite detailed control of where I'm dragging to.

1509.text: So if I do this the image at the bottom says do I want to update the image so I'm now at the region I've chosen here

1516.text: or do I want to reset the scrollable region back to where I was before.

1522.text: If I change my tool option and I go for this dotted box instead

1527.text: Now whenever I put my mouse over this box, I get this red dotted line, the mouse stays as a Mickey Mouse hand.

1537.text: What I can do now is if I click and drag out a box

1542.text: it offers me the option of marking the region or jumping to the region,

1546.text: so that's another way I can navigate around.

1548.text: I will get rid of that box.

1551.text: And now we'll move down and look at the more detailed view at the bottom.

1556.text: So we've still got our contig, we've still got our chromosome bands,

1561.text: and we've still got our genes but our genes are shown in much more detail.

1564.text: We've got exon and intron structure, and we've also split our genes into two different tracks.

1569.text: So 'tracks' is a very genome-browser-y word

1573.text: When we say 'tracks' what we mean is one particular kind of data that you see plotted onto the view.

1581.text: So we would say that the genes are a track, we would say that this CCDS, which are these green genes here, they're a track,

1590.text: the contigs are a track. So it's just a bit of jargon that we use quite regularly.

1598.text: So our genes are shown top and bottom, and the genes that are shown at the top are positively stranded

1605.text: and the genes that are shown at the bottom are negatively stranded.

1610.text: We've also got some other positive and negatively stranded features

1613.text: So these cDNAs, the CCDS, we've got them at the top but also at the bottom.

1618.text: Things like chromosome bands, they're not stranded so they're shown at the very top,

1623.text: and at the bottom we've got regulatory features and variation data

1629.text: which is also, and GC content, also data that is not stranded,

1634.text: so anything that is not stranded will be shown at the very very top or the very very bottom.

1639.text: Whereas anything that is stranded will be shown on either side of the contig depending on what strand they're on

1645.text: We have a legend at the bottom here telling us what all these colours in the display actually mean.

1652.text: Now this is a view that I can manipulate, I can change, I can make it show me different kinds of things

1658.text: depending on what I'm interested in. And I can do is either using this little cog

1663.text: or using the 'Configure this page' button. So if I click on 'Configure this page',

1669.text: this takes me to a menu that shows all of the different tracks are available for this view,

1674.text: and you can see there are a lot of tracks. For human we have thousands of tracks available.

1681.text: So you can see the names of the tracks, this is just showing us the ones that are currently switched on

1688.text: and if I click on the info button that goes with each track, I can see a description of the track.

1697.text: So you might want to open that up if you're not sure what a track might actually be.

1703.text: Because there are so many tracks, we've provided you with navigation down the left

1707.text: to help you to find the tracks that might be of interest to you

1711.text: so I can click on 'Variation' if I'm interested in variation data

1715.text: then I can click on 'dbSNP variants' and you can see it give me different options for how I want the track to be displayed.

1722.text: Now the easiest thing I find is to turn it on in a particular style, see if it gives you the data you need,

1728.text: and if it doesn't, change it. I'm going to turn it on in 'Normal'.

1733.text: And the other way you can find tracks, so we found them quite easily using the categories,

1738.text: if you're not sure what category it might be in, or you want to get to it quite quickly,

1742.text: if you don't want to scroll through lists, you can use 'Find a track', which is up here at the top right hand.

1748.text: So if I write the word 'protein' that will find all the tracks with the word protein

1754.text: either in the description, in which case the description will be shown,

1758.text: or in the name. So I'm going to turn on the proteins from Uniprot in mammals, which I'm going to put in 'Normal'.

1765.text: I can now save and close the menu.

1769.text: We had a question in the live webinar, so I'll just let you know now,

1773.text: about saving configurations. So you can click on this button 'Save configuration as...'

1779.text: so if you've found a configuration you use regularly, you can save it

1785.text: and it'll save it to your session, so if you go back to the same computer it will remember you using cookies,

1792.text: but you could also set up an account and I'll just show you that when we come out of the menu.

1798.text: I can come out of the menu, I can either click on the tick,

1802.text: but I've made my mouse really giant, so you can see it, which make it very difficult for me to click on things

1808.text: so I'm going to click anywhere outside the menu, which will also work.

1814.text: You can see it's loading. While that's loading, I'll just point out that if you want to set up an account with us

1819.text: there's this 'Login/Register at the top right. And it's completely free and nobody ever send you spam emails.

1826.text: So having filled the time by chatting, you'll see that I've now added some data.

1833.text: So I've added some proteins, which is stranded data, so we've got one at the top and one at the bottom,

1840.text: and I've added these dbSNP variants as well

1843.text: Now if you have added data, there is a quick way to change without going into the 'Configure this page' menu,

1852.text: So I cna hover over the track name, you'll see it gives me the info again

1857.text: and I can change the style, so I could change it to labels, I can also turn it off as well if I wanted to.

1864.text: So if I turn it to 'Labels' I will now see, when it loads,

1874.text: We call this the spinning E of death

1878.text: We can now see the labels that go with the proteins, so these will be the Uniprot IDs.

1883.text: I can move stuff around as well, so if I want to view these dbSNP variants alongside these genes here,

1889.text: you can see that when I put my mouse over this bar on the left, it turns into this double-headed arrow.

1896.text: I can now click and drag and move it so it's alongside other data,

1901.text: it makes it easier for me to compare two different kinds of data next to each other.

1907.text: Having found something that I think is interesting, I might want to share it with my colleagues,

1912.text: which is all very well if my colleague is the person on the desk next to me,

1916.text: I can call them over, we take a look.

1918.text: But it's a bit more complicated if my colleague is somebody who works over on the different side of an ocean.

1926.text: Now, if we take a look at the URL shown here at the top,

1930.text: obviously what you're thinking is that I'll just copy and paste that and email this page.

1935.text: If you look at the URL, you can see it's telling us we're in Ensembl, we're in human, we're at a location,

1941.text: we're viewing it, and this is the location we're looking at. That's just telling us which database we're in.

1946.text: It doesn't tell us anything about the tracks we've added or the manipulation that we've done.

1953.text: So if I was sending that to somebody they would get to the same region

1957.text: but they wouldn't see all the bits and bobs, if you've done lots of manipulation,

1961.text: it might take them quite a while and quite a lot of description to get them into the same place that you're in.

1966.text: The solution to this is this 'Share this page' button, over on the left-hand side.

1972.text: When I click on 'Share this page, it generates a link

1976.text: and this link includes all of the information that's included in this region view.

1982.text: So it's not just the location but it's also all of the tracks that I've added

1987.text: and when Ben gives you the demo on uploading your own data to Ensembl

1994.text: you'll see that when you try the Share link you get a little tick box

1998.text: with the option of do you want to include your own data as well

2002.text: I can now put that in an email I can send it to my colleague and they can be looking at the same thing that I'm looking at.

2011.text: I'll just get rid of that.

2013.text: The last thing I want to show you, actually there's a few more things sorry.

2017.text: I mentioned about the drag and select tool in the view above.

2021.text: You've also got it here, and I just want to point out

2025.text: If I'm interested in this exon, I might zoom in, so I can do a jump to region.

2032.text: There is also this bar to zoom in if you prefer.

2034.text: But let's say I do a jump to region on this exon,

2041.text: I decide that I'm really interested in these variants here

2046.text: I can drag out a box around them, I can say 'Mark region'.

2052.text: Then we'll zoom out by dragging out a box here. So drag out a box here, 'Jump to region'.

2068.text: So when I did the 'Mark region' you see it gives me this grey box, and they grey box is still there.

2076.text: So if I find something really interesting when I'm zoomed in, I can then zoom out

2080.text: and keep it marked and and not lose track of where it was I was looking at.

2084.text: Then when I'm done with it, I can just get rid of it using this box here.

2087.text: The last thing, definitely this time the last thing,

2092.text: when you're going through some of the exercises you'll find that you do add quite a lot of tracks

2097.text: into the region view and it can get very very busy when you add lots and lots of tracks

2101.text: and it becomes hard to see what it is you're trying to focus on.

2105.text: So what I recommend doing, at the end of every exercise

2108.text: is going to the 'Configure this page' menu, scrolling down and hitting 'Reset configuration',

2114.text: which will take you back to the original configuration state

2123.text: OK, so I'll hop back into my presentation

2131.text: and I've just got a few things to show you for wrapping up today's webinar.

2136.text: So I've given you the introduction to Ensembl,

2141.text: please do come back on the 31st March where Denise wil be talking about Ensembl genes

2146.text: and also to our further webinars.

2149.text: So Denise will talk about the automated pipelines that we use to annotate genomic assemblies

2155.text: as well as the manual annotation that we present alongside this.

2159.text: And she'll take you through the Gene Tab and she'll show you the range of data that you can get

2165.text: Those of you who are tuning in live, please note the time.

2169.text: Our daylight saving time is taking place this weekend,

2174.text: so if you've already had your daylight saving time you're not having a daylight saving time,

2178.text: please do take note the next week's webinar will be an hour earlier than this one

2185.text: and all further ones will be at that particular time.

2190.text: For those of you who were in the live webinar, this was the point when I gave you the option of putting questions int the chat box,

2198.text: I will hope over this now, but a lot of people did take advantage of this when we did this live.

2204.text: The course exercises are available when you go into the online course on EBI Train Online

2211.text: I will just briefly show you. So here we are on the Train Online course,

2217.text: As soon as I've finished making and processing this video, I will replace this text

2223.text: and you can see that we've got the exercises shown, that you can have a go at

2230.text: and also solutions to the exercises.

2233.text: So as well as asking for help on the Facebook group and emailing us

2238.text: you can just have a look at some of the answers that we've got there.

2257.text: So as I mentioned, please do have a look at the Facebook group and join

2261.text: if you would like to discuss the exercises with other people.

2265.text: There is absolutely tons of help and documentation on Ensembl outside of this course,

2271.text: many of you will have come in through EBI Train Online, there are tons of courses,

2276.text: not just on Ensembl, but on various other topics available there.

2281.text: We have our YouTube and our YouKu channels for short tutorials to take you through specific aspects

2290.text: similar to the one with Denise that I showed you earlier.

2295.text: And you can also email us, we are helpdesk@ensembl.org.

2299.text: If you would like to follow us through social media, we do have Facebook, Twitter,

2305.text: and we also have a blog. The blog's really interesting if you're interested in

2309.text: background to particular new kinds of data then we will give you a bit of background to new stuff in the blog as well

2317.text: We publish papers, if you do use our data, please do cite us.

2322.text: This is the team as of June last year,

2326.text: so some of the people who'll be giving the webinars and helping out are shown in this

2332.text: as well as all the people who are producing all the data and interfaces you can see.

2337.text: Just to say thank you to everybody who takes part in the project and also our funders as well,

2344.text: it would not be possible to deliver either the data and the website that we have

2350.text: or the course that we do without the funding that we have.

2356.text: So thank you for attending, I hope it was useful to you and I hope we see more people back for the next set of webinars.
